channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Who are the Americans freed in a Russian prisoner swap? And, Simone Biles is GOAT
item.description: Americans were welcomed home last night after the largest prisoner exchange between the West and Russia since the end of the Cold War. And, Simone Biles secures her GOAT status at the Olympics.
item.content:encoded:
Americans were welcomed home last night after the largest prisoner exchange between the West and Russia since the end of the Cold War. And, Simone Biles secures her GOAT status at the Olympics.

(Image credit: Alex Brandon)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Russian opposition figure, Vladimir Kara-Murza, was released in prisoner swap
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks to Alina Polyakova, of the Center for European Policy Analysis, and a friend of Vladimir Kara-Murza, who was recently freed in a Russia-U.S. prisoner swap.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks to Alina Polyakova, of the Center for European Policy Analysis, and a friend of Vladimir Kara-Murza, who was recently freed in a Russia-U.S. prisoner swap.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: Kamala Harris is expected to pick her running mate in the next few days
item.description: What’s it feel like waiting to hear if you’re chosen to be the vice presidential nominee? NPR's A Martinez talks to Sen.Tim Kaine of Virginia who knows what's it is like.
item.content:encoded: What’s it feel like waiting to hear if you’re chosen to be the vice presidential nominee? NPR's A Martinez talks to Sen.Tim Kaine of Virginia who knows what's it is like.
item.dc:creator: A Martínez

item.title: With no federal standard for heat, states are making their own to protect workers
item.description: There is currently no federal heat law, but states have been passing protections as workers toil in extreme temperatures.
item.content:encoded:
There is currently no federal heat law, but states have been passing protections as workers toil in extreme temperatures.

(Image credit: Emily Hofstaedter)
item.dc:creator: Emily Hofstaedter

item.title: A woman addicted to methamphetamine says becoming a mother turned her life around
item.description: In this week's StoryCorps, a mother talks with her son about how she overcame her addiction to drugs.
item.content:encoded: In this week's StoryCorps, a mother talks with her son about how she overcame her addiction to drugs.
item.dc:creator: Jey Born

item.title: Olympic Village cafeteria serves 40,000 meals a day to the world’s best athletes
item.description: We take a peak behind the curtain at the Olympic Village, inside the cafeteria that's been called the world's largest restaurant.
item.content:encoded: We take a peak behind the curtain at the Olympic Village, inside the cafeteria that's been called the world's largest restaurant.
item.dc:creator: Hosts

item.title: Bangladesh is witnessing the deadliest protests in its history
item.description: Activists want the autocratic prime minister to step down.
item.content:encoded: Activists want the autocratic prime minister to step down.
item.dc:creator: Diaa Hadid

item.title: The U.S. is being urged to help lower the escalating tensions in the Middle East
item.description: What options does the U.S. have to tamp down tensions in the Middle East? NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with former U.S. Ambassador to Israel Edward Djerejian.
item.content:encoded: What options does the U.S. have to tamp down tensions in the Middle East? NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with former U.S. Ambassador to Israel Edward Djerejian.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: New blood tests can help diagnose Alzheimer's. Are doctors ready for what's next?
item.description: A new generation of blood tests can help diagnose Alzheimer’s disease. But many doctors don’t yet know how to use them.
item.content:encoded:
A new generation of blood tests can help diagnose Alzheimer’s disease. But many doctors don’t yet know how to use them.

(Image credit: Marcus Brandt/picture alliance)
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: Inflation math is changing America's dinner plans
item.description: For the first time in years, people are buying more groceries, including pricier brands, to replace restaurant outings. From McDonald's to Starbucks, fast food and cafes are feeling it.
item.content:encoded:
For the first time in years, people are buying more groceries, including pricier brands, to replace restaurant outings. From McDonald's to Starbucks, fast food and cafes are feeling it.

(Image credit: Steven Pruitt)
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh
